summary:
I am an archaeologist with museum experience and a passion for culture and heritage, which I am keen to share as widely as possible, making it relevant to modern day society. I completed my BA in Ancient History and Archaeology at Durham University (2011) and hold an MPhil in European Prehistory from the University of Cambridge (2012). I worked as an assistant curator in the archaeology department of the Drents Museum (Assen, the Netherlands), before starting an AHRC-funded PhD project on the later prehistoric East Anglian Fens at Durham University in October 2014. I undertook placements at the British Museum (UK) and the Moesgaard Museum (Denmark) and worked as a research assistant at Wageningen University and Research (2019-2020) and the Cambridge Archaeological Unit (2019-2020). In 2020 I became curator of Archaeology at the Drents Museum, where I was responsible for the Archaeology collection, which I shared with as wide and diverse an audience as possible through research, publications and exhibitions.

Currently, I am a postdoctoral researcher at the School of Archaeology at University College Dublin, where I contribute to the 'Animals and Society in the Bronze Age Project'. This project aims to explore the role of animals as active participants in Bronze Age social worlds, rather than passive objects of consumption. My research focusses on 'animal architectures', which I study to investigate human-animal interaction and spatial engagement at different levels (from farms to settlements and the landscape). To analyse these spaces of encounter and interaction, I will identify animal-related features and examine how animals moved across the landscape.

treasury_media.title: dr. FJ (Floor) Huisman
treasury_media.description: I am a landscape archaeologist interested in human-environment interaction, landscape perceptions, identity and social relations, particularly in and around wetlands.

treasury_media.title: Floor Huisman
treasury_media.description: The latest Tweets from Floor Huisman (@FJHuisman). Archaeologist interested in public archaeology and all things nature and culture.

education.degree_name: Associate Fellow of the Higher Education Academy

education.grade: Cambridge Certificate of Proficiency, Grade A

projects.title: Conference session: Wetlands vs. Drylands? Challenging divides and changing archaeological perspectives on prehistoric wetland sites, landscapes and societies (European Association of Archaeologists' Annual Meeting session)
projects.description: I co-organised and ran a session at the European Association of Archaeologists' Annual Meeting in Barcelona in which we explored archaeological perspectives on wetland sites and communities in relation to dryland(er)s.

projects.title: Fieldwork: Daskalio excavation
projects.description: I was one of five trench supervisors during a Cambridge University led excavation on the small Greek island of Daskalio.  I was responsible for a team of three to five archaeologists excavating one of five trenches. As trench supervisor I was responsible for setting out the excavation aims each day, and dividing up tasks between team members. I also recording the progress of the excavation using the innovative digital i-Dig recording programme (run on i-pads in the field), handwritten and igital notes and digital photography. As part of my team consisted of inexperienced field school students, my responsibilities also included elements of fieldwork training, teaching students he basics of excavation and recording techniques. I worked closley with the Project leaders, discussing progress and future aims and reported on progress in bi-weekly team meetings.

projects.title: Training: Northern Bridge Digital Illustration course
projects.description:
Having secured a Student Innovation Forum grant of c. 7500 pounds from the Northern Bridge Doctoral Training Partnership, a fellow PhD candidate from Newcastle University and I initiated and organised a training course in digital illustration for fellow PhD students. We approached a course facilitator, send out applications and selected participants for a two day training course on the use of Adobe Illustrator at beginner's and intermediate level. We also organised a keynote lecture on the use and creation of effective visualisations and organised the follow-up 'Strategic Partner Project', in which participants of the digital illustration course were asked to design a product for one of the Northern Bridge's strategic partners. 

Tasks and responsibilities during the preparations for this course included liasing with Northern Bridge directors and administrative staff, the course facilitator, keynote speaker, student participants and several Northern Bridge partner representatives, such as the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art, Durham Castle and the Great North museum: Hancock. We also created a programme for the course and the Strategic Partner Project and managed the running of the training course, the keynote lecture and the Strategic Partner Project, in addition to participating in these various events.

projects.title: Conference: Climate Change and Human Society
projects.description: Having secured funding through the 'Research Dialogues' funding scheme from the Archaeology Department at Durham University (subsequently suplemented by funding from the Centre for Academic Researcher Development (CARD) and the Institute of Hazard, Risk and Resilience (IHRR), both Durham University), I initiated an interdisciplinary postgraduate conference on climate change and human society. Responsibilities include: liaising with keynote speakers, speakers and delegates from across the UK and beyond, selecting papers and planning plus organising registration and the programme, ordering catering, boooking venues, travel and accommodation.

projects.title: Fieldwork: Herm Project 2011
projects.description: In the last season of the investigation of the buried Neolithic landsurface and occupation traces on the island of Herm, I was one of four trench supervisors, leading a team of three students. I was responsible for documenting and recording the excavation process in detail using analogue and digital methods.

projects.title: Fieldwork: Herm Project 2010
projects.description: During the investigation of the buried Neolithic landsurface on the island of Herm I excavated one of several trenches in a team of four, gaining basic fieldwork and recording skills. Herm being a popular tourist destination, this position also entailed informing a wide variety of people face-to-face about the project and finds.

projects.title: Exhibition: Labyrinthia
projects.description: I worked as part of the Drents Museum team on the new collection presentation of the Drents Museum. In this presentations, made in collaboration with exhibition makers Bruns, designers NorthernLight en multimedia specialists from YIPP, archaeolgy, history and art come together in the beatiful setting of the old museum building. Aimed at new audiences, including families and children, the presentation is an interactive, multimedia experience which will allow visitors to explore the museums collection and its stories in a hands-on manner. I conributed to the development of the concept and storylines and was responsible for three of the rooms within this presentation, each of which tells a different story. I wrote the storyline for these rooms, selected objects, wrote the exhibition texts and collaborated closely with designers to create the exhibits. Together with the other curators, I also contributed to various educational layers within the presentation and several outreach programmes and products which will appear alongside the new collection presentation (due to open in 2023).

projects.title: Crowdfunding project: Een mantel voor ons meisje
projects.description: In the context of the Drents Museum's new collection presentation Labyrinthia, I inititated new research into the textiles found with the Yde Girl Bog body, aiming to present her in a more human fashion (rather than as a gruesome sacrificial victim). I brought together a research team to examine the textiles and create a reconstruction of the cloak she wore for the new exhibit. Working closely with internal and external colleagues from crowdfunding organisation Voordekunst, we designed a crowdfuning campaign, aiming to fund the research and cloak reconstruction. As project leader, I was responsible for writing the project proposal, providing information on Yde Girl and her textiles to all parties involved, for creating a budget proposal and for contacting and liaising with numerous external researchers and conservators, all involved in the project. Due to illness of a key team member, the project has been postponed indefinitely.

projects.title: Exhibition: Dying in beauty - The world of Pompeii and Herculaneum
projects.description: I was involved in the first stages of this temporary exhibition, making contact with Italian colleauges, with whom I developed the basic concept for the exhibition and made a first selection of objects.

projects.title: Exhibition: Under the spell of Mount Ararat - Treasures from ancient Armenia
projects.description: I took over as project leader from my predecessor (who retired) to realise this exhibition, which was postponed twice due to the COVID-pandemic. I was responsible for restarting the dormant project and my main focus was the exhibition content (objects, catalogue and texts), editing and proofreading exhibition and catalogue texts and helping to install the objects. In this capacity I also lead and assisted both in and external colleagues in the lead-up to this exhibition, for instance by contributing to educational and outreach programmes.

projects.title: Online content: Peatland exchanges
projects.description: Together with colleagues from Wageningen University and Research, I contributed an online presentation about the museum's bog finds to the Peatland Exchanges, a series of interdisciplinary online presentations on peatlands, organised by Kate Foster, artist in residence at the World Soil Museum.

projects.title: Online content: Canon van Nederland
projects.description: I contributed short texts on two 'key pieces' from the museum's collections to the Dutch canon website. I wrote a short text on what the Yde Girl bog body can tell us about life above the Roman limes, and a short piece on the early medieval Roswinkel hoard, which reflects 'pagan' practices in Charlemagne's Christian empire.

projects.title: Exhibition: Veenpark redesign
projects.description: Together with two colleagues I provided input for a number of new displays in the cottages of the Veenpark, an open air museum telling the story of peat digging in Drenthe. I was responsible for researching 18th and 19th century daily life and working conditions in the raised bogs of Drenthe. I collected organised and shared this information with the exhibition designers, who used my input and that of my colleagues to create the new exhibits now on display.

projects.title: Art project: Spaghnum Time
projects.description: I contributed to Sissel Marie Tonn's art installation 'Spaghnum Time', in which fictional bog bodies tell us theri story, by providing access to and information about a number of bog bodies in the museum's collection.

projects.title: Research project: Wet Futures
Conference: Landscape and Identity: Interdisciplinary explorations of being in the world
projects.description: After my PhD, a PhD-student in Durham's Classics Department and I secured funding through the Institute of Advanced Studies (Durham University) to initiate and organise an interdisciplinary postgraduate conference on Landscape and Identity: Interdisciplinary Explorations of Being in the World. Scheduled for early 2020, this was sadly cancelled due to the COVID-pandemic. Responsibilities include: budgetting funding, finding co-organisers in different departments, writing the call for papers, liaising with speakers and delegates from across the UK and beyond, selecting papers, creating a programme, planning and organisation (venue, accommodation, funding).

projects.title: Research project: Wild wetlands and domestic drylands? Prehistoric communities of the East Anglian Fens in their broader regional context (c. 4000 BC - 100 AD)
projects.description: My PhD research project at Durham University aimed to examine the role and place of wetland(er)s in relation to dryland(er)s by contextualising later prehistoric (c. 4000 BC-100 AD) wetland sites and communities in the East Anglian Fens (UK). It examined how wetland(er)s fit in the wider socio-cultural and physical landscape by considering past human-environment interaction and its social outcomes through time. I studied food remains in and around the former Fens to understand how the wetlands were used throughout time. I then used social theories current in mainstream Archaeology to examine how people’s identities were constructed through their interaction with the wetland environment and to assess to what extent ‘wetlander’ identities may have affected people’s relations with others.

projects.title: Fieldwork: Iraq Emergency Heritage Management Training Scheme
projects.description: I worked for five weeks as a trench supervisor on the British Museum led Iraq Emergency Heritage Management Project in Rania, Kurdistan, Iraq. This government-funded project aims to train archaeologists from across the whole of Iraq in cultural heritage management and practical fieldwork skills. As trench supervisor I was responsible for planning the excavation strategy, and recording contexts, features and finds by digital and analogue methods. In addition I was involved int the training of two Iraqi participants in the scheme, teaching them general excavation and recording skills in the field and helping with report writing and software training in the afternoon. Other responsibilities include daily data entry, digitising drawings in Adobe Illustrator, writing biweekly reports and writing a final summary report.

projects.title: Online content: Web-pages on Grauballe Man
projects.description: During my placment at the Moesgaard Museum I created a series of English web-pages the Grauballe Man bog body.

projects.title: Fieldwork: South-East Naxos Island Survey Project
projects.description: As one of seven team leaders, I was responsible for three or four archaeology volunteers during this Cambridge University led fieldwalking project on the island of Naxos in Greece. As team leader I was responsible for planning our walking routes through difficult terrain, navigating and the general well-being of the team. I also recorded the landscapes we encountered and entered field notes into a digital database each day.

publications.name: Wet worlds in context –The prehistoric East Anglian Fens and their regional setting
Misreading the marshes: past and present perceptions of the East Anglian Fens, UK
publications.publisher: R. O'Sullivan et al. (eds.), Archaeological Approaches to Breaking Boundaries: Interaction, Integration and Division, British Archaeology Reports (BAR), pp. 105-116.

publications.name: Two Late Bronze Age Hoards from the Yorkshire Wolds, Driffield, East Riding, Yorkshire
Must Farm, een tijdscapsule uit de bronstijd
Chapter sections in the catalogue accompanying the ‘Mummies: Life Beyond Death’ exhibition
publications.publisher: Van Vilsteren. V. (ed.), Mummies: overleven na de dood, WBooks, Zwolle, the Netherlands.

publications.name: Historisch Nieuws: 'Hier kom ik weg'. Daniël Lohues' persoonlijke geschiedenis van (Zuid-Oost) Drenthe

courses.name: Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) Writing for Lay Audiences workshop
Geographical Information Systems (GIS) in Archaeology and related Humanities
Humanities and the Public Good: influencing public policy through research
Introduction to Quantitative Data Analysis for Social Sciences and Humanities
Northern Bridge Relational Database Course II
Northern Bridge Relational Database Course II
Thinking Across Borders: Developing an on-line network for young researchers in the humanities

profile_positions.description: Currently, I am a postdoctoral researcher at the School of Archaeology at University College Dublin, where I contribute to the 'Animals and Society in the Bronze Age Project'. This project aims to explore the role of animals as active participants in Bronze Age social worlds, rather than passive objects of consumption. My research focusses on 'animal architectures', which I study to investigate human-animal interaction and spatial engagement at different levels (from farms to settlements and the landscape). To analyse these spaces of encounter and interaction, I will identify animal-related features and examine how animals moved across the landscape.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description: As coordinator of the Schervenlab in Castle Ammersoyen I coordinate, support and work closely with a group of volunteers to sort, describe and document the thousands of sherds found in the castle's moat. In addition to working with this collection and the volunteers, I am involved in public outreach, informing visitors about our work and the importance of the collection for our understanding of life at Ammersoyen in the medieval period.
profile_positions.title: Coordinator ArcheoHotspot Schervenlab Ammersoyen Castle

profile_positions.description: As curator of Archaeology I was responsible for the archaeology collection at the Drents Museum. I shared this collection with a broad audience through research, publications and exhibitions.
profile_positions.title: Curator of Archaeology

profile_positions.description: In this role as a research assistant on the 'Wet Futures' project I interviewed a variety of stakeholders around the former island of Schokland about their understanding of this landscapes and the heritage within it, and the way they want to manage this World Heritage Site.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: I worked as a research assistant at the Cambridge Archaeological Unit. In this role I participated in fieldwork projects and post excavation activities, including data-basing and archiving, data collection and analysis, and writing publication texts in close conjunction with Project Directors and specialists.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
At the Oriental Museum I helped running the Family Activities. In this role I welcomed families with children, explained the activity of the week (mostly art and craft based), supplied them with the necessary materials and assisted carers and children when needed. 

After this role became voluntary, I worked as a custodian and front of house staff member at the reception and information desk on on a casual basis. I assisted visitors by answering their queries, selling tickets, food and drinks as well as items from the shop.
profile_positions.title: Custodian

profile_positions.description:
I worked for five weeks as one of four trench supervisors on the British Museum led Iraq Emergency Heritage Management Project in Rania, Kurdistan, Iraq. In this role I lead a team of ten local workmen and trained two Iraqi participants during the excavation of a Parthian building (c. 1st-3rd c AD) in Iraq.
I was responsible for planning the excavation strategy, and recording contexts, features and finds by digital and analogue methods (photography, context sheets, notebook, plans, sections). In addition I was involved int the training of two Iraqi participants in the scheme, teaching them general excavation and recording skills in the field and helping with report writing and software training in the afternoon.
Other responsibilities include daily data entry, digitising drawings in Adobe Illustrator, writing biweekly reports and writing a final summary report.
profile_positions.title: Trench supervisor

profile_positions.description: An two-month Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) Northern Bridge Doctoral Training Partnership (NBDTP) funded placement at the Moesgaard Museum, during which I created an English website on the Grauballe Man bog body (https://www.moesgaardmuseum.dk/en/exhibitions/permanent-exhibitions/grauballe-man/) and was responsible for creating, updating and maintaining an overview of all objects included in the major temporary exhibition ‘On the steppes of Genghis Khan – Mongolia’s Nomads’, produced in close collaboration with the National Museum in Denmark.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description: I worked as a part time tutor on two level 1 undergraduate courses (‘Discovering World Prehistory’ and ‘Archaeology in Action’) in 2015 and 2017, marking essays and running small group tutorials. In this role I liaised with course convenors and other postgraduates teaching on these modules, to ensure effective delivery of material between the teaching team. I worked with small groups (c. 5-8 students) across the academic year to discuss course content and apply this to relevant examples. I also helped students develop important academic skills (like referencing, writing, reading) and marked formative essays and presentations, providing both written and oral feed-back.
profile_positions.title: Tutor

profile_positions.description: A two month internship funded by the AHRC Northern Bridge Doctoral Training Partnership. During this placement I mostly worked on Treasure cases, describing and researching objects brought in via the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) and writing reports on these items for the coroner. I was also involved in researching various objects in the collection in preparation for a BBC radio show which is to run alongside a major exhibition. For this I wrote short fact-sheets on the selected objects. I also worked in the stores, organising, describing and relabelling a collecton of Fenland material and photographing objects which I then uploaded to the British Museum's online catalogue.
profile_positions.title: Intern

volunteer_experiences.role: SSCC and Research Committee representative - Department of Archaeology
volunteer_experiences.description: I volunteered to be one of the Student Staff Consultative Committee representatives in the Archaeology Department at Durham University. I represented the postgraduate research students (PGRs) with four ohter PhD students. Together, we were responsible for gathering and presenting fellow students' views and complaints in SSCC meetings and for reporting back issues discussed to the students. Additionally, we organised social events for PGRs. I sat on the Research Committee, where I liased between staff and the postgraduate research student cohort and organised research related events.

During my PhD research I joined a team from the Cambridge Archaeological Unit on a voluntary basis for the excavation of the well-preserved Bronze Age wet-land site Must Farm in the East Anglian Fenlands for a total of five weeks.

I was elected secretary of Trevelyan College's Middle Common Room (MCR) by fellow MCR members. I was responsible for all communication between MCR members and the MCR Executive Committee. I wrote and distributed a weekly digital newsletter on all events and activities in college and answered questions from MCR members. I was also responsible for minuting Exec and MCR meetings and updating the MCR website, notice boards and calendar.
Edited the Dutch translation of a short visitor’s guide enabling Dutch visitors to the Ontario Museum to learn about and enjoy Ontario’s rich heritage and First Nation history.

company.name: Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Cambridge

volunteer_experiences.description: Welcomed visitors, answered their queries and where possible engaged them.

I was elected by peers as a course representative for fellow students on the Staff Student Consultative Committee (SSCC) in the Archaeology Department of Durham University. In this role I liaised with fellow students and staff to identify and solve issues related to the Ancient History and Archaeology course.
A voluntary position in a local organisation providing archaeological and heritage services. Activities included excavation, find cleaning and cataloguing, pottery refitting and drawing of finds.
Worked independently in a Fairtrade shop, and was responsible for helping customers, keeping stock records, stocking, cleaning and tidying, opening and closing and cashing up.
